intro: Gayophytum nuttallii var. intermedium, commonly known as the intermediate gayophytum, is a flowering plant native to the southwestern United States and northern Mexico. It belongs to the Malvaceae family, which includes hibiscus and cotton, and is characterized by its showy, trumpet-shaped flowers. The plant typically grows in rocky soils and arid environments, showcasing adaptations to drought conditions. Its leaves are palmately lobed, and the flowers come in shades of pink to red, attracting pollinators such as bees and butterflies. This variant is distinguished by intermediate traits between the two main varieties of Gayophytum nuttallii.
